awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the principal investigator's research on the theory of automorphic forms, a special topic in the general area of number theory. Number theory has its historical roots in the study of natural numbers. It is among the oldest branches of mathematics. Within the last half century it has become an indispensable tool, with diverse applications in areas such as data transmission and processing, communication systems, and internet security. 
 
In more detail, the project centers on the theory of automorphic forms. The main goal of the project is to develop the automorphic descent method, which provides construction of automorphic forms on classical groups. The PI will establish identities relating the constructed automorphic forms to the data used in the descent construction. The PI will also investigate the application of these identities to a quantitative refinement of the Gan-Gross-Prasad conjecture, which is a conjecture that can be viewed as a far-reaching local to global principle for period integrals.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we study the Rankin-Selberg method in automorphic forms. The Rankin-Selberg method was first developed for representations that are generic. The PI, with E. Lapid, developed the Rankin-Selberg method for a class of representations that are far from generic, called the Speh representations. We also used the automorphic descent (which is an application of the Rankin-Selberg method) to study the identities relating Whittaker period of a representation with its L-values. We were able to solve the global aspect of this problem and reduce the question to the proof of a local identity. We developed a formal argument for the local identity, unfortunately we were not able to produce a rigorous argument. Only in the case of representations over a metaplectic group we produced a complete result by giving a local proof. Later following our argument K. Morimoto gave a complete proof in the case of unitary group.

In the final year of this project the PI served as chair of his department in Rutgers University at Newark, which has one of the most diverse student body in the nation. PI led the department effort in education reform and human resource development. The department teaches 2000-3000 students each semester, has over 400 Majors and Minors studying Mathematics, Computer Science and Data Science. With newly created Computer Science courses, our students for the first time are able to complete Computer Science degree without taking courses from other institutions. We are building a Data Science Minor program from ground up, recently introducing ten new Data Science courses. We participate in EveryoneLearningEverywhere program, also expand the use of adaptive software in the basic math courses. We engage in outreach activities for middle school and high school students. The PI also co-organized Junior Number Theory Days workshop at Rutgers-Newark, organized PI-Day math tournament for middle school students, and help developed a website mathcup.com which is a free platform for math enrichment aimed at elementary school and middle school students.
